Award.AwardTitle: Predicting the Lifetime of Polymer Pipes in Corrosive Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Low cost polymers are increasingly used for civil infrastructure applications such as pipes for water and natural gas delivery, corrugated drainage pipes, sanitation pipes, and geomembranes. In these applications, the combination of mechanical loading and environmental conditions can accelerate degradation of the polymer and lead to crack formation and propagation referred to as stress corrosion cracking (SCC). The main feature of SCC is the evolution of multiple small cracks with failure ultimately occurring when one of these cracks propagates. The lifetime of polymer components can vary significantly due to the randomness of mechanical and transport properties of polymer materials. In this project, a numerical model will be developed that combines the fracture behavior with the diffusion of the liquid environment and subsequent degradation of the polymer. A series of experiments will be performed in which the mechanical properties of the polymer are characterized as a function of polymer degradation. The statistical variation in these properties is the cornerstone for predicting the variability in polymer lifetime. This research will advance our understanding of probabilistic SCC in polymers. In addition, it will provide engineers a scientific method to design polymer pipes for a prescribed failure risk, which will improve the structural reliability of pipes used for civil infrastructure applications. The educational plan includes activities targeted for a range of constituents at various levels of expertise: a high school camp that utilizes a web-based tool for pipe design, webinars for polymer industry professionals, and university courses for undergraduates and graduate students.

As compared to existing approaches for design of polymer components, which are primarily based on a deterministic framework, this research is anchored by a probabilistic framework. By including the effects of uncertainties in various material properties (i.e., mechanical properties, chemical diffusivity and molecular weight), the model can capture the overall stochastic response of polymers in a corrosive environment. This research will lead to the following important results: 1) a stochastic chemo-mechanical model for SCC in polymers that characterizes the interactions between the chemical diffusion process, chemical-induced material degradation and crack propagation; 2) a methodology and experimental data to quantify the relationship between degradation of mechanical properties and molecular weight; 3) model validation through an experimental study of crack growth in a corrosive liquid environment; and 4) a reliability-based design method for polymer pipes, which will allow engineers to design pipes for a desirable lifetime at a tolerable failure risk.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Polymers are increasingly used for structural applications because of their corrosion resistance and low cost compared with metals. Structural uses of polymers for infrastructure applications (without reinforcing fibers) include: pipes for water and natural gas delivery, corrugated drainage pipes, sanitary pipes, geomembranes, and geogrids.  In many cases, the polymer components are exposed to a corrosive environment that, when combined with structural loads, can lead to premature failure: the combination of stress and oxidation leads to stress corrosion cracking (SCC). 

In this project, a method for modeling stress corrosion cracking and the associated lifetime of polymer structural components was developed.  The study included characterization of the changes in morphology and mechanical properties in a semicrystalline polymer commonly used in piping and geomembranes, high density polyethylene (HDPE).  These properties were the basis of a constitutive model of the elasto-viscoplastic material behavior as a function of the extent of degradation.  The effect of the corrosive environment is intrinsic to the mechanical model.  In the case of semicrystalline polymers this link is the molecular weight and crystallinity. The model is applicable for the broad class of semicrystalline polymers and was incorporated into a commercial finite element code.  The model captures the change from ductile to brittle behavior as the material degrades. 

The work provides a robust tool for predicting the lifetime of polymer components.  The associated publications include a case study that shows good prediction of failure trends for pipes. We have established a facility for exposing polymers to highly oxidative environments.  Mechanical test fixtures and procedures have also been developed that are appropriate for evaluating materials that range from very ductile (virgin material) to quite brittle.  These developments have led to significant international collaborations, with exchange of personnel and publications.

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts include:  1. Community education, 2. Recruitment of female students, and knowledge transfer to the engineering community.  Two instructional modules for K-12 have been developed under the umbrella of a national organization, ?Market Science?, in which research teams set up a booth at local farmers markets. The research team included  2 PhD students (1 female), 2 MS students (1 female), and 8 undergraduates (4 females).  The work to date has also been disseminated in 11 journal or conference publications.  In addition, the work was the basis of a keynote talk, a topic in a technical monograph, and formed the basis of several conference sessions for the Failure Analysis and Prevention group of the Society of Plastics Engineers.   

 


Last Modified: 08/28/2019
Modified by: Susan C Mantell

Structural uses of polymers for infrastructure applications (without reinforcing fibers) include: pipes for water and natural gas delivery, corrugated drainage pipes, sanitary pipes, geomembranes, and geogrids. In this project, a method for modeling stress corrosion cracking and the associated lifetime of polymer structural components was developed. The study included characterization of the changes in morphology and mechanical properties in a semicrystalline polymer commonly used in piping and geomembranes, high density polyethylene (HDPE). These properties were the basis of a constitutive model of the elasto-viscoplastic material behavior as a function of the extent of degradation. The effect of the corrosive environment is intrinsic to the mechanical model. In the case of semicrystalline polymers this link is the molecular weight and crystallinity. The model is applicable for the broad class of semicrystalline polymers and was incorporated into a commercial finite element code. The model captures the change from ductile to brittle behavior as the material degrades. The work provides a robust tool for predicting the lifetime of polymer components. The associated publications include a case study that shows good prediction of failure trends for pipes. We have established a facility for exposing polymers to highly oxidative environments. Mechanical test fixtures and procedures have also been developed that are appropriate for evaluating materials that range from very ductile (virgin material) to quite brittle. These developments have led to significant international collaborations, with exchange of personnel and publications. Broader Impacts: The broader impacts include: 1. Community education, 2. Recruitment of female students, and knowledge transfer to the engineering community. Two instructional modules for K-12 have been developed under the umbrella of a national organization, ?Market Science?, in which research teams set up a booth at local farmers markets. The research team included 2 PhD students (1 female), 2 MS students (1 female), and 8 undergraduates (4 females). The work to date has also been disseminated in 11 journal or conference publications. In addition, the work was the basis of a keynote talk, a topic in a technical monograph, and formed the basis of several conference sessions for the Failure Analysis and Prevention group of the Society of Plastics Engineers.
